title: Needs vs Wants Categorization Game
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Personal Finance
Budgeting
Financial Literacy
description: An interactive game where students practice categorizing expenses as needs (essential) or wants (discretionary), developing critical budgeting skills through gameplay with immediate feedback.
topic: Needs vs Wants, Budgeting Fundamentals, Expense Categorization
learningObjectives: Define and distinguish between needs (essential expenses) and wants (discretionary expenses)
Apply the needs vs wants framework to categorize real-world expenses correctly
Analyze context-dependent expenses to determine when circumstances change categorization
Evaluate personal spending to identify opportunities for financial improvement
Understand that context matters in financial decision-making
prerequisites: Basic understanding of financial vocabulary (expense, budget, income)
Concept of limited resources requiring choices
Understanding that people make trade-offs with money
accessibility: Large text sizes (28px for main content)

controls.name: NEED
controls.description: Click to categorize the current expense as a need (essential)

controls.name: WANT
controls.description: Click to categorize the current expense as a want (discretionary)

controls.name: IT DEPENDS
controls.description: Click when the expense category depends on individual context

controls.name: Reset Game
controls.description: Restart the game with shuffled expenses

parameters.name: Expense Items
parameters.purpose: Variety of realistic expenses covering housing, food, transportation, entertainment, insurance, education, and personal care

parameters.name: Difficulty Levels
parameters.purpose: Progressive complexity to develop analytical skills

variables: gameComplete (whether all expenses have been categorized)
assumptions: Context for 'needs' is basic survival, safety, and ability to earn income
Modern context includes internet and phone as needs for most people
Some expenses are genuinely context-dependent without a single 'right' answer
limitations: Does not account for all individual circumstances and contexts
Simplified categorization may not reflect real-world gray areas completely
Does not address cultural differences in what constitutes needs vs wants
Fixed set of expenses may not reflect all student experiences
educationalStandards: National Standards for Financial Literacy: Standard I (Earning Income), Standard III (Saving)
Jump$tart Coalition: Financial Responsibility and Decision Making
Council for Economic Education: Personal Finance Competency Areas
assessmentOpportunities: Observe reasoning during class discussion of ambiguous items
Evaluate student's ability to categorize their own real expenses
Quiz on explaining why specific items are categorized as needs or wants
